volsense_inference package

Submodules

volsense_inference.analytics module

VolSense Analytics — Trader Snapshot Module

Lightweight analytical layer for daily volatility forecasts. Generates actionable metrics, relative signals, and visualizations for multi-ticker forecasts without requiring historical data.

This module is intended for use within volsense_inference.

class Analytics(preds: DataFrame, vol_regime_quantiles: List[float] = [0.2, 0.8])[source]

Bases: object

Trader-facing analytics for VolSense forecasts.

Parameters:

  • preds (pandas.DataFrame) – DataFrame with columns like [‘ticker’,’realized_vol’,’pred_vol_1’, …].

  • vol_regime_quantiles (list[float], optional) – Quantile thresholds (low, high) for regime classification.

Raises:

ValueError – If an empty or None forecast DataFrame is provided.

compute() → DataFrame[source]

Compute cross-sectional volatility analytics for a single snapshot.

Derives per-horizon metrics:

  • f/r ratio: forecast_vol / realized_vol

  • z-score: cross-sectional z-score vs realized_vol mean/std

  • signal_strength: clipped z-score in [-3, 3]

  • vol_regime: ‘Low Vol’ | ‘Normal’ | ‘High Vol’ via quantiles

Returns:

Processed DataFrame with added per-horizon columns and ‘vol_regime’.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

describe(ticker: str, horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5') → str[source]

Produce a human-readable interpretation for a single ticker.

The message encodes direction via f/r ratio (>1 rising, <1 easing), the cross-sectional z-score, and the volatility regime.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) – Ticker to describe.

  • horizon (str) – Horizon column to reference (e.g., ‘pred_vol_5’).

Returns:

Short interpretation string for trader consumption.

Return type:

str

plot(horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5', show: bool = False)[source]

Scatter plot of forecast vs realized volatility at a selected horizon.

Each ticker is plotted as a labeled point; includes a 45-degree reference line.

Parameters:

  • horizon (str) – Horizon column to plot (e.g., ‘pred_vol_5’).

  • show (bool) – If True, render and close the figure; if False, return the Figure.

Returns:

Matplotlib Figure when show=False; otherwise None.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure or None

summary(horizon: str = 'pred_vol_5') → DataFrame[source]

Summarize realized vs forecast metrics for each ticker.

Returns a compact table with:

[‘ticker’,’realized_vol’,’forecast_vol’,’f/r_ratio’,’zscore’,’vol_regime’].

If the requested horizon is absent, falls back to the first available ‘pred_vol_*’ column.

Parameters:

horizon (str) – Horizon column to summarize (e.g., ‘pred_vol_5’).

Returns:

Ticker-level summary sorted by descending z-score.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

volsense_inference.dashboard module

Streamlit dashboard for VolSense.

Provides a small interactive UI to run forecasts, inspect per-ticker plots, sector heatmaps and cross-sectional signals. —————————————

This module exposes the Streamlit application and several helper functions:

  • _parse_tickers() - parse user comma-separated tickers

  • _safe_style_format() - style numeric columns for display

  • _detect_horizons() - detect forecast horizons from dataframe columns

  • _load_forecast_model() - cached model loader

  • run_volsense() - run forecasts + signals (cached)

  • export_csv_button() - download button for DataFrame CSV export

Typical usage

Run the Streamlit app:

streamlit run volsense_inference/dashboard.py
export_csv_button(df: DataFrame, filename: str, label: str = '📥 Export CSV')[source]

Create a Streamlit download button that exports a DataFrame as CSV.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – DataFrame to export.

  • filename (str) – Suggested filename for the downloaded CSV.

  • label (str) – Button label text.

Returns:

None

run_volsense(model_version: str, checkpoints_dir: str, start: str, tickers: List[str])[source]

Run VolSense forecasts and compute analytics and signals.

This function is cached for 30 minutes to avoid repeated expensive runs.

Parameters:

  • model_version (str) – Model version to use for forecasting.

  • checkpoints_dir (str) – Directory with model artifacts.

  • start (str) – Start date string for feature fetch.

  • tickers (List[str]) – List of tickers to forecast.

Returns:

Tuple (Forecast instance, predictions DataFrame, analytics object, analytics summary DataFrame, SignalEngine instance, signals DataFrame)

Return type:

tuple

volsense_inference.forecast_engine module

volsense_inference.forecast_engine

High-level forecasting runtime for VolSense.

This module exposes the Forecast runtime class which orchestrates data fetching, feature engineering, batch inference against a pretrained VolSense model, and lightweight analytics and visualization helpers.

Primary class

Forecast

  • Loads a pretrained model and its artifacts (scalers, metadata, feature list) via volsense_inference.model_loader.load_model.

  • Prepares recent market data using volsense_core.data.fetch.build_dataset and volsense_core.data.feature_engineering.build_features to ensure the inference inputs match the training-time schema.

  • Runs batched inference using volsense_inference.predictor.predict_batch, attaches realized volatility values, and exposes an Analytics helper for cross-sectional signal computations and simple plots.

Usage example

>>> from volsense_inference.forecast_engine import Forecast
>>> f = Forecast(model_version="v507", checkpoints_dir="../models", start="2020-01-01")
>>> preds = f.run(["SPY", "QQQ"])
>>> f.plot("SPY")

Notes

  • The Forecast class expects model artifacts to be available in the checkpoints directory (meta + state or supported bundle format). See volsense_inference.model_loader for loading behavior and supported formats.

  • Forecast.plot produces a matplotlib Figure when show=False, otherwise it renders and closes the figure to avoid duplicate captures in notebook contexts.

class Forecast(model_version: str = 'v109', checkpoints_dir: str = 'models', start: str = '2005-01-01')[source]

Bases: object

High-level runtime interface for volatility forecasting and visualization.

Orchestrates:

  • recent data fetch and feature engineering aligned to the trained model,

  • batched inference for one or more tickers,

  • attachment of realized volatility for the snapshot date,

  • light analytics and plotting helpers.

model_version

Version tag of the pretrained model assets to load.

Type:

str

checkpoints_dir

Directory containing model checkpoints and metadata.

Type:

str

start

Earliest date used when fetching recent data to build features.

Type:

str

Loaded model ready for batch prediction.

Type:

object

Model metadata (e.g., horizons, window).

Type:

dict

Per-ticker scalers used during training.

Type:

dict

Mapping of ticker symbols to integer IDs.

Type:

dict

Feature columns expected by the model.

Input window length used by the model.

Type:

int

Lookback window for realized volatility computation in feature prep.

Type:

int

Forecast horizons supported by the model.

Type:

list[int]

predictions

Last forecast snapshot produced by run().

Type:

pandas.DataFrame | None

Analytics helper attached after run().

Analytics

plot(ticker: str, show_vix: bool = False, vix_df: DataFrame = None, show: bool = True)[source]

Plot realized volatility history and overlay constant forecast levels by horizon.

Draws:

  • Realized volatility time series for recent months.

  • Horizontal dashed lines for each available predicted horizon.

  • Optional VIX overlay if provided.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) – Ticker symbol to visualize.

  • show_vix (bool) – Whether to overlay VIX time series (requires vix_df).

  • vix_df (pandas.DataFrame, optional) – DataFrame with columns [‘date’,’close’] representing VIX levels.

  • show (bool) – If True, render the plot and return None; if False, return the Figure.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – If .run() has not been called prior to plotting.

  • ValueError – If no forecast results are available for the requested ticker.

Returns:

Matplotlib Figure when show=False; otherwise None.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure or None

run(tickers)[source]

Generate multi-horizon forecasts for one or more tickers.

Prepares recent data, runs batched predictions, attaches realized volatility, and computes cross-sectional analytics for convenience.

Parameters:

tickers (str or list[str]) – Ticker symbol or list of symbols to forecast.

Returns:

Forecast snapshot with columns like [‘ticker’,’pred_vol_1’,’pred_vol_5’,…,’realized_vol’].

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

volsense_inference.model_loader module

Model loader utilities for VolSense inference.

This module provides a single entrypoint load_model() which locates and loads model artifacts saved in one of three supported formats:

  • legacy “.full.pkl” (pickled model or bundle)

  • combined “<stem>_bundle.pkl” (dict with state + meta)

  • portable “<stem>.meta.json” + “<stem>.pth” (state_dict + metadata)

All loaders return a tuple:

(model, meta, scalers, ticker_to_id, features)

The module focuses on safe CPU-device loading and conservative defaults so artifacts saved on different environments (Colab, local) can be loaded reliably.

Sphinx-style documentation is provided on public helpers.

load_model(model_version: str, checkpoints_dir: str = 'models', device: str = 'cpu')[source]

Universal VolSense model loader.

This function attempts to locate and load artifacts for model_version from checkpoints_dir. Supported artifact layouts (priority order):

  1. <stem>.full.pkl

  2. <stem>_bundle.pkl

  3. <stem>.meta.json + <stem>.pth

The returned tuple contains:

(model, meta, scalers, ticker_to_id, features)

Parameters:

  • model_version (str) – Version identifier matching checkpoint stems (e.g. “global_vol_forecaster_multi_v507”).

  • checkpoints_dir (str) – Relative directory name containing model artifacts.

  • device (str) – Torch device to move the loaded model to (default “cpu”).

Returns:

Tuple with loaded model and auxiliary metadata/assets.

Return type:

tuple

Raises:

FileNotFoundError – If no supported artifact layout is found for the version.

Example:
>>> model, meta, scalers, t2i, features = load_model("global_vol_forecaster_multi_v507", "models", device="cpu")

volsense_inference.predictor module

VolSense Inference — Predictor

Helper utilities to run single and batched predictions with pretrained VolSense models.

Responsibilities: - Resolve the expected feature list from model metadata or user override. - Apply per-ticker scaling using training-time scalers, with sensible fallbacks. - Execute model forward passes with optional ticker ID conditioning. - Produce per-ticker predictions and aggregate batch results. - Attach latest realized volatility for comparison and derive simple diffs.

Used by volsense_inference.forecast_engine.Forecast.

attach_realized(df_preds: DataFrame, df_recent: DataFrame) → DataFrame[source]

Attach the latest realized volatility to each forecast row and compute diffs.

When df_recent contains ‘realized_vol’, merges the most recent value per ticker into df_preds, then computes simple diagnostics:

  • vol_diff = pred_vol_1 - realized_vol

  • vol_direction = sign(vol_diff)

If ‘realized_vol’ is not available in df_recent, the input df_preds is returned unchanged.

Parameters:

  • df_preds (pandas.DataFrame) – DataFrame of predictions with one row per ticker.

  • df_recent (pandas.DataFrame) – Recent feature DataFrame containing realized volatility history.

Returns:

DataFrame augmented with ‘realized_vol’ and derived diagnostics when available.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_batch(model: Any, meta: Dict[str, Any], df: DataFrame, tickers: List[str], scalers: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, ticker_to_id: Dict[str, int] | None = None, features: List[str] | None = None) → DataFrame[source]

Run predictions for a list of tickers and return a tidy DataFrame.

Exceptions for individual tickers are caught and printed; failed tickers are skipped.

Parameters:

  • model (Any) – Loaded model used for inference.

  • meta (dict) – Model metadata/config dictionary.

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Feature DataFrame containing multiple tickers.

  • tickers (list[str]) – List of ticker symbols to predict.

  • scalers (dict[str, Any], optional) – Optional dict mapping ticker -> fitted scaler.

  • ticker_to_id (dict[str, int], optional) – Optional mapping from ticker to integer ID expected by the model.

  • features (list[str], optional) – Optional explicit feature list to override meta-derived list.

Returns:

DataFrame with columns [‘ticker’,’pred_vol_…’] for available horizons.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_single(model: Any, meta: Dict[str, Any], df: DataFrame, ticker: str, scalers: Dict[str, Any] | None = None, ticker_to_id: Dict[str, int] | None = None, features: List[str] | None = None) → Dict[str, float][source]

Predict multi-horizon volatility for a single ticker.

Aligns features to the model schema (adding missing features as zeros, dropping extras), scales inputs with the appropriate per-ticker scaler, runs the model, and formats outputs as {‘ticker’, ‘pred_vol_1’, ‘pred_vol_5’, …} using horizons from meta.

Parameters:

  • model (Any) – Loaded model used for inference.

  • meta (dict) – Model metadata/config including ‘window’, ‘horizons’, and optional ‘config.target_col’.

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – Feature DataFrame containing rows for multiple tickers and dates.

  • ticker (str) – Ticker symbol to predict.

  • scalers (dict[str, Any], optional) – Optional dict mapping ticker -> fitted scaler for features.

  • ticker_to_id (dict[str, int], optional) – Optional mapping from ticker to integer ID expected by the model.

  • features (list[str], optional) – Optional explicit feature list to override meta-derived list.

Raises:

ValueError – If there is insufficient data to form the input window.

Returns:

Dictionary with ‘ticker’ and predicted volatility per horizon.

Return type:

dict[str, float]

volsense_inference.sector_mapping module

VolSense Inference — Sector mappings and color palettes.

This module centralizes:

  1. Ticker-to-sector dictionaries for different model universes: - SECTOR_MAP_109: compact universe used by v109 models - SECTOR_MAP_507: extended universe used by v507 models

  2. SECTOR_COLORS: consistent hex colors per sector for plots/dashboards

Helpers:

  • get_sector_map(version): obtain the appropriate ticker→sector map

  • export_to_json(path): write both maps to a JSON file for external use

  • get_color(sector): fetch a stable color for a sector label

Intended for analytics, dashboards, and reporting layers in volsense_inference.

export_to_json(path='sector_map.json')[source]

Export available sector maps to a single JSON file.

The JSON contains two top-level keys: “v109” and “v507”.

Parameters:

path (str) – Filesystem path to write the JSON file.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

get_color(sector: str) → str[source]

Get a consistent hex color for a given sector label.

Parameters:

sector (str) – Sector name (e.g., ‘Technology’, ‘Financials’).

Returns:

Hex color string (e.g., ‘#1f77b4’); defaults to light gray if unknown.

Return type:

str

get_sector_map(version: str = 'v109') → dict[str, str][source]

Return the ticker-to-sector mapping for a given model version.

Parameters:

version (str) – Model version key (‘v109’ for small map, ‘v507’ for large map).

Raises:

ValueError – If the version key is not recognized.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping ticker symbols to sector names.

Return type:

dict[str, str]

volsense_inference.signal_engine module

VolSense Signal Engine (Snapshot Edition)

Transforms snapshot forecasts from ForecastEngine or ForecasterAPI into actionable volatility signals and sector-level intelligence.

Key changes vs. prior version:

  • Removed metrics needing time-series history (EMA, momentum, spillover)

  • Treats realized_vol as today’s realized volatility

  • Renamed realized_vol → today_vol for interpretability

  • Cleaned & vectorized computations for speed

  • Simplified sector-relative rollups and cross-sectional scoring

  • Added cross-sectional sector z-score computation for single-day analysis

class SignalEngine(data: DataFrame | None = None, model_version: str = 'v109')[source]

Bases: object

Snapshot signal processor for cross-sectional and sector intelligence.

Converts a one-day, multi-ticker forecast table into z-scores, spreads, ranks, regime flags, and sector-relative statistics.

Parameters:

  • data (pandas.DataFrame, optional) – Optional forecast DataFrame to initialize and standardize.

  • model_version (str) – Sector-map key (‘v109’ or ‘v507’) used for enrichment.

Variables:

  • df (pandas.DataFrame | None) – Canonical input DataFrame after coercion.

  • signals (pandas.DataFrame | None) – Computed signal DataFrame after compute_signals().

  • sector_map (dict[str, str]) – Mapping of ticker to sector label for the chosen universe.

compute_signals(enrich_with_sectors: bool = True) → DataFrame[source]

Compute cross-sectional signals from the snapshot.

Derives per-horizon:

  • vol_zscore: Cross-sectional z-score of forecast_vol

  • vol_spread: (forecast_vol / today_vol) - 1 when today_vol is available

  • xsec_rank: Percentile rank by horizon

  • signal_strength: Rescaled rank in [-1, 1]

  • regime_flag: {‘calm’,’normal’,’spike’} by z-score thresholds

  • (optional) sector-level rollups and z-scores

Parameters:

enrich_with_sectors (bool) – If True, attach sector labels and sector stats.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If no data has been loaded via set_data().

Returns:

Signal-enriched DataFrame aligned to the canonical schema.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

ticker_summary(ticker: str, horizons: list[int] | None = None, date: Timestamp | None = None, decimals: int = 4) → str[source]

Create a human-readable summary for a ticker across horizons.

Includes forecast level, today’s realized vol, percent spread, z-score, position, regime, sector z-score, and universe rank.

Parameters:

  • ticker (str) – Ticker symbol to summarize.

  • horizons (list[int] | None) – Subset of horizons to include; defaults to all present.

  • date (pandas.Timestamp | None) – Snapshot date; defaults to the max date in signals.

  • decimals (int) – Decimal precision for displayed values.

Returns:

Multi-line summary string for the selected ticker.

Return type:

str

Raises:

RuntimeError – If compute_signals() has not been called.

classify_position(row)[source]

Classify a trading position from cross-sectional and term spreads.

Parameters:

row (Mapping[str, float]) – Mapping-like object (e.g. pandas.Series) containing at minimum: vol_zscore (float). Optional keys: vol_spread (float) and term_spread_10v5 (float).

Returns:

Position label: "long", "short", or "neutral".

Return type:

str

Raises:

KeyError – If vol_zscore is missing from row.

Note

Decision thresholds (hard-coded):

  • z-score threshold: > 1.0 → high, < -1.0 → low

  • vol_spread threshold: > 0.07 / < -0.07 (±7%)

  • term_spread_10v5 threshold: > 0.035 / < -0.035 (±3.5%)

Example

>>> classify_position({'vol_zscore': 1.2, 'vol_spread': 0.08})
'long'
>>> classify_position({'vol_zscore': -1.3, 'term_spread_10v5': -0.05})
'short'
